Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Ultrasound-Guided Subclavian Vein Puncture Techniques

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the traditional group (n=30) or the improved group (n=30).

Participants.evidence: Conducted at the Air Force Specialty Medical Center, this randomised controlled trial included 60 patients requiring right subclavian vein catheterization.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the traditional group (n=30) or the improved group (n=30).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an improved ultrasound-guided subclavian vein puncture technique compared to the traditional method.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the one-time puncture success rate, assessed immediately post-procedure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the traditional group (n=30) or the improved group (n=30).

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis, with all 60 participants included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The improved group achieved a higher one-time puncture success rate (80% vs. 66.7%) and reduced procedure time (mean difference = 5.0334 minutes, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: The improved group experienced fewer complications (10% vs. 37%; p < 0.05), with reduced incidences of pneumothorax and hematoma.
